children.subject: Cool! What do you think about taking Stat 134 AND Stat 135, yknow just to get a feel for "real world data interpretation skills"

I'm not a stat major and 134 is the only upper-div stat class I've taken so sadly I can't comment on that. If you don't get a response from someone on here, try posting in the STAT 001 piazza (its basically like this but for stat majors).

Stat135 gives you a look at the core tenants of statistical inference, such as hypothesis testing (but at a much higher level with Likelihood Ratios etc), tests of homogenity, tests of independence, and a deep dive into the mathematics behind regression (you'll prove a lot of the identities surrounding regression). 

However, if you're looking for real world data skills, Data100 might be a better fit (and Stat134/140 + Data100 is a nice combo). The issue with Stat135 is that it's pretty theory based (which I enjoyed in some part bc I'm a theory person), but also a little dated in its applications. Data100 will touch on some similar regression topics (so you have the same high level of understanding, but you won't prove a lot of the mathematical stuff in Data100), but also on useful real world topics like train-test splits, cross validation, bias-variance tradeoff and model/data interpretations. 

I'd recommend checking out the Data100 website  and take a look at the fa18 Stat135 stat135sum18Syllabus1.pdf to see which topics draw your interest more.

Another note about "real-world" applications - if that's what you're going for, then 140 might be a better fit. While the 134 and 140 content is pretty similar, 140 has much more modern applications of the probability theory you learn. For example, in my semester of 140 (it was a while ago so I'm not sure if they still have this lab), we decoded an encrypted piece of text with Markov Chain theory, which was super cool to me!. However, 140 is an extremely popular class, so unless you have a really good registration time, 134 might be easier to get into. 

You can also play your bets and waitlist in both and see which one you get into first ;)

If your goal is to just gain a great understanding of probability, look into Stat 134 instead. The two are essentially identical courses in terms of probability content (so identical, in fact, that once you've taken one you cannot take the other for credit).  

Stat 134 differs from 140 in that it is a more classical take on probability and doesn't include coding/data science applications to the material itself. As a result, no linear algebra or coding is done in the class (unlike 140) and the workload is far lower (weekly psets are just 6 problems a week, 140 has longer HWs in addition to weekly labs). This isn't to say that 134 is a significantly easier class, however. 

The first half of 134 is essentially all the probability from CS70 at a much slower yet more in-depth pace. The second half deals with continuous probability and requires a good calculus foundation (mainly integrals and some series). 

Stat 134 is far easier to get into (i got into it this semester with just a couple of weeks before classes starting), so it might be a great option for you!
I'm a non-DS, non-Stats with no enrollment priority and got in without much stress during the Fall of my senior year by phase 1ing it. Took data 100 (not data 8).

history.content: You can take Data 100 instead of Data 8 and have the same likelihood of getting into the class as you would with Data 8. If you have neither of those, your chances of getting into the class are pretty low

I know you have to wait list for people who did take data8. Has anyone had experience with this (I'm not really willing to do the work for data 8.. just want to leave college with a more solid understanding of probability, now that I'm not stressed about memorizing and non-stop grinding 70 problems to try to declare)
history.subject: Odds of getting into Prob 140 as a graduating senior without Data 8?
